Kaifuyi Tongsansi, Specially Advanced, Probationary Chief Minister for Making Loud Announcements,

Duke of Su, with an Estate of Three Thousand Households, Bestowed with Purple, Posthumously Granted the Title of Minister of Works, Posthumously Honored with the Great Mirror, with the Great Wisdom, Tripiá¹­aka Master Amoghavajra of the Daxingshansi Monastery, Translated by Imperial Order. At that time, King Udayana was alone in a quiet room, sitting in meditation, and gave rise to this thought:
How can I know the true faults and true virtues of all kings?
If I know them, I will abandon their faults and cultivate their virtues.
Who among the pure practitioners of Å›ramaá¹‡as can explain this to me in detail?
After a long time of contemplation, he had this thought:
Only my World-Honored One, the Great Teacher of the Three Realms, who possesses omniscience, definitely knows the true faults and true virtues of all kings.
I should now go to the Buddha, the World-Honored One, and ask about this meaning!
Therefore, I have come to the Buddha. I only wish that the TathÄgata will explain it for me.
World-Honored One!
What are the true faults of kings?
What are the true merits of kings?
Having made this request,
at that time the World-Honored One told King Udayana:
Great King!

You should now understand the faults of a king, the merits of a king, the doors to the king's decline, the lovable dharmas of a king, and the dharmas that can give rise to a king's lovable [qualities].
What are the faults of a king?
Great King, you should know!
The faults of a king are briefly of ten kinds. If a king accomplishes such faults, even if he has a great treasury, great ministers and aides, and a great army, he is not to be relied upon.
What are the ten?

First, not having a high family lineage, second, not having independence, third, having a violent and evil nature, fourth, being fierce and quick to anger, fifth, being stingy with favors, sixth, accepting flattery, seventh, not following the rules established by ancient kings, eighth, not caring about good laws, ninth, not distinguishing right from wrong, superior from inferior, and tenth, being unrestrained and indulging in wanton behavior.
What is meant by the king not having a high family lineage?
It means being born from a commoner or lower class, not from a noble family, and usurping the throne. This is called not having a high family lineage.
What is meant by the king not having independence?
It means that an emperor is constrained by his ministers, aides, and officials, and does not act as he wishes;
in all his actions, he is always advised and restrained, and he is also not satisfied with the five desires and does not enjoy himself and play as he wishes.
This is called the king not having independence.
What is meant by the king having a violent and evil nature?
It means that when a king sees his ministers or other people commit a minor offense or transgression, he immediately speaks harsh words to their face, is furious, scowls, and demotes them;
even if he does not do so to their face, he turns his back on them and does the above-mentioned scolding and other things to others;
he may not be angry for a long time, or he may not give up for a long time:
such face-to-face violence and back-to-back violence are called the king's violent nature.
What is meant by the king's fierce anger?

It means that when a king sees his ministers have a minor offense or transgression, he immediately reduces their fiefs and salaries, takes away their wives and concubines, and punishes them with heavy laws.
This is called the king's fierce anger.
What is meant by the king's meager rewards and favors?

It means that a king, his ministers, and others are close to him and serve him. Although they are extremely pure and good, they comfort him with soft words, and the bestowal of titles, rewards, and honors is not perfect and does not follow the usual style;
or after a loss or delay, he then gives them.
This is called the king's grace and favors being slow and thin.
What is meant by the king accepting evil flattery?

If an emperor sees that his ministers are not truly loyal and upright, are not familiar with the laws and regulations, secretly conspire to assist and advise, have biased and flattering minds, do not practice good governance, and are jealous of good and virtuous people;
and he trusts the words and advice offered by such people, because of this, the king's affairs, wealth, fame, and good governance all decline.
This is called the king accepting evil flattery.
What is meant by the king not following the laws established by his predecessors?

It means that a king is unable to investigate and examine the various ministers, and in matters of various affairs and state laws, he entrusts those who are not capable while not entrusting those who are capable, he punishes those who should be rewarded while rewarding those who should be punished;

Moreover, in the great court assembly, while other discussions are not yet finished, he interrupts and speaks, without respect or fear, and starts debates and disputes, unable to follow the law and properly carry out his duties, and cannot properly abide by the teachings and orders of the former king.
This is called not following the laws established by the former king.
What is meant by a king not caring for good dharmas?

It means that there is a king who does not believe in cause and effect, does not understand the good and bad karma that will come in the future, the rewards of humans and gods, and acts according to his emotions, creating the three kinds of evil deeds with his body, speech, and mind. He is not able to give timely gifts, cultivate blessings, observe the precepts, learn the precepts, receive the Dharma of the abhiá¹£eka of dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, and does not promote the practice of the four immeasurables. Such a king is called one who does not care about good dharmas.
What is meant by a king who does not discern right from wrong, superior from inferior?

It means that there is a king who uses his mind in a topsy-turvy way towards his great ministers, chief counselors, and officials, and is not good at understanding the differences in loyalty and trustworthiness, skills and arts, and wisdom.

Because of not knowing, he has the notion of loyalty and trustworthiness towards those who are not loyal and trustworthy, the notion of skills and arts towards those who do not have skills and arts, the notion of good wisdom towards those with bad wisdom, and the notion of bad wisdom towards those with good wisdom.

Moreover, the ministers who are old and feeble, who have been close attendants for a long time, are known to be powerless, and thus are not respected or loved, not granted rank or emoluments, not rewarded, and are despised by others, abandoned and not consulted.
This is called the king not discerning right and wrong, the superior and the inferior.
What is meant by the king being unrestrained and indulging in excessive indulgence?

It means that the emperor is completely immersed in the five desires, indulging in play, unable to admonish and be cautious from time to time, to do what should be done, and to comfort and encourage the ministers.
This is called being unrestrained and indulging in excessive indulgence.
If a king possesses these ten faults, even if he has a great treasury, great assistants, and a great army, his realm will naturally fall into chaos and cannot be relied upon for long.
Great King, you should know these ten faults:
The first is the fault of the king's lineage, the remaining nine are the faults of the king's own nature.
What is meant by the king's merits?
Great King, the king's merits are, in brief, of ten kinds:

First, noble lineage; second, great autonomy; third, not being violent by nature; fourth, having slight anger; fifth, fierce generosity; sixth, accepting straightforward words; seventh, well-considering what is to be done, and skillfully following previous teachings; eighth, caring for good dharmas; ninth, well-knowing distinctions; tenth, not being self-indulgent, and not being negligent.
What is meant by the king's noble lineage?

It means that a king, having planted good roots in the past, due to the power of great vows, is born in the royal clan, succeeds to the throne, nourishes the myriad people, and has pure faith in the Three Jewels.
This is called the king's noble lineage.
What is meant by the king's great autonomy?
It means that the king, according to his own wishes, delights in and enjoys the five sublime desires, bestows rewards as he pleases, and issues orders to his hundred officials without obstruction.
This is called the king attaining great self-mastery.
What is meant by the king's nature being not violent or evil?

It means that when the king sees that his ministers have committed even minor offenses, he is able to tolerate them and does not immediately demote them, does not speak harshly, does not become angry in their presence, and does not secretly harbor resentment in his mind.
This is called the king's nature being not violent or evil.
What is meant by the king's anger being light?

It means that even if the king's ministers have great offenses and great transgressions, he does not completely deprive them of their fiefs and emoluments, nor does he take away their wives and concubines, nor does he punish them with heavy laws, but acts with leniency according to the seriousness of the offense. This is called the king's anger being light.
What is meant by the king's favors being swift?

It means that when there are ministers who are close to the king and serve him with a pure heart and a well-disciplined mind, the king will from time to time console them with proper and perfect gentle words, bestow honors and rewards upon them, and not cause them to suffer losses, delays, hardships, or resentment. They are easy to befriend and not difficult to serve.
This is called the king's favors being swift.
What is meant by the king accepting straightforward words?

It means that when there are ministers who are truly loyal, upright, free from corruption, and impartial, who are well-versed in the laws and regulations, and who have no disloyalty in their hearts, the king trusts the words and advice offered by such people. Because of this, the affairs of the state and wealth and treasures are all accomplished, his reputation spreads far and wide, and the people are all joyful.
This is called the king accepting straightforward words.
What is meant by the king's actions being well-considered and in accordance with the teachings of the previous kings?

It means that there is a king who is able to investigate and discern various matters of public law among the various ministers, and those who are not suitable for entrustment are not entrusted, while those who are suitable for entrustment are entrusted;
those who should be rewarded are properly rewarded, and those who should be punished are properly punished;
whatever he does, he thinks and chooses carefully, and then acts without haste.

Although the king and his ministers are in court, they never speak in the middle of the discussion, but wait until the end of the speech to offer advice and debate, and they follow the king's teachings well.
This is called following the teachings of the previous kings.
What is meant by the king cherishing good dharmas?

It means that there is a king who believes in cause and effect, good and bad karma, and the fruits of human and heavenly beings. He is endowed with a sense of shame, but does not indulge in doing the three kinds of evil deeds with his body, speech, and mind. From time to time he gives generously, cultivates blessings, observes the precepts, establishes maá¹‡á¸alas, receives the abhiá¹£eka method, and performs homa offerings to the holy assembly. The four immeasurables always harbor extensive salvation.
Such a king is called one who cherishes good dharmas.
What is meant by a king who can discern right and wrong, superior and inferior?

It means that a king, in regard to his ministers, chief counselors, and officials, is free from mental confusion. He is well able to understand the differences in loyalty, skills, and wisdom, whether they exist or not. He knows them as they truly are. He disregards and distances himself from those who lack them, and respects and loves those who possess them.

Moreover, the ministers who are old and feeble, who have been close attendants for a long time, although knowing they have no power and strength, still remember their past kindness, turn to cherish respect and love, and do not despise them. Rewards and honors are distributed without fail. This is called the king who can discern right and wrong, the superior and the inferior.
What is meant by the king not being self-indulgent and not acting recklessly?

It means that the king does not become immersed in the five desires, does not become arrogant and attached to frivolous play, but is able to admonish and be cautious from time to time, to do what should be done and comfort the ministers. This is called the king not being self-indulgent and not acting recklessly.
If a king accomplishes these merits, even if he has no treasury, no great assistants, and no great army, his realm will naturally become prosperous and people will look up to him before long.
Great King, you should know that these are the ten merits of a king:
The first is called the merit of the royal lineage, and the remaining nine are called the merits of the royal nature.
What are the gates of the king's decline?
Great King, you should know!
There are five kinds of gates of the king's decline:

First, not skillfully investigating and employing the ministers; second, although skillfully investigating, lacking kindness and generosity, even if there is kindness and generosity, it does not arrive in time; third, exclusively indulging in negligence, not thinking about state affairs; fourth, exclusively indulging in negligence, not guarding the treasury; fifth, exclusively indulging in negligence, not cultivating good dharmas.
These five kinds are all called the gates of the king's decline.
What is meant by the king not skillfully investigating and employing the ministers?

It means that there is a king who cannot thoroughly investigate and carefully examine the distinctions in loyalty, skill, and wisdom among his ministers, and he includes them in his close attendants, favors them, bestows them with thick rewards and emoluments, and entrusts them with important positions, often comforting them with gentle words;

yet the wealth and treasures entrusted to these ministers are often lost or wasted. If they encounter enemies, evil friends, or an army, they will first retreat and be defeated, and in fear they will flee and turn their backs, without any loyalty to their lord.
This is called the king not observing well and including his ministers.
What is meant by the king observing well but being without kindness and generosity, and even if he is, it is at the wrong time?
It means that there is a king who is able to thoroughly investigate and carefully examine, knowing who is loyal, skilled, and wise, and includes them in his close attendants, but does not favor them;
he does not measure their abilities and does not bestow rewards and emoluments on them;
in critical situations, he does not entrust them with important tasks.
Suddenly, at one time, the king encountered a great fear from enemies, evil friends, and the battlefield. In the face of urgent danger, he bestowed honors and comforted them with soft words.
At that time, the ministers said to each other:
The king, due to the present perilous circumstances, is temporarily bestowing kindness upon us, not out of a long-term mind!
Knowing this, although there are those who are loyal, trustworthy, skilled, and wise, they all hide and do not appear.
This is called the king who, although skillfully observing, does not bestow kindness when gathering the ministers, and even if he does, it is not at the right time.
What is meant by the king indulging in negligence and not thinking about state affairs?

It means that there is a king who does not from time to time stay in an empty and quiet place alone or together with wise people, and does not properly contemplate and understand the affairs that should be harmonized and accomplished, such as the affairs of the country, and the affairs that should be rewarded and even the affairs that should be accomplished in the military array, and does not pay attention to them.
This is called the king who indulges in negligence and does not think about the affairs of the country.
How is it that the king indulges in negligence and does not guard the treasury?

It means that there is a king who engages in few activities, does not observe the affairs, does not control the royal gate, palace courtyard, and treasury, reveals the confidential matters of the state to women, and wastes wealth and treasures on hunting and gambling, and does not carefully protect them.
This is called the king who indulges in negligence and does not guard the treasury.
How is it that the king indulges in negligence and does not cultivate good dharmas?

It means that there is a king who cannot often approach, pay homage, and consult with the Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who are gentle and honest, have wisdom and eloquence, and have attained liberation in the world, asking: What is good?
What is not good?
What is sinful?
What is sinless?
What is the Dharma gate of blessings and auspiciousness that is far removed from evil?
Even if one hears it, one does not practice in accordance with it.
Such a king is called one who indulges in self-indulgence and does not cultivate good dharmas.

If a king accomplishes these five gates of decline and loss, one should know that this king will lose the rewards of the present world, and even in the next life he will lose the blessings of humans and gods.
Namely, the first four gates lose the benefits of the present life, and the last gate loses the rewards of the next life.
What is called the Dharma that the king loves?
Great King, you should know!
In brief, there are five kinds, namely, the Dharma that the king loves, delights in, rejoices in, and approves of.
What are the five?

First, being respected and loved by the people; second, having increased authority; third, being able to subdue enemies; fourth, being able to take good care of one's body; fifth, being able to cultivate wholesome activities.
These five are the lovable, enjoyable, delightful, and agreeable dharmas of the king.
How does one skillfully give rise to the lovable dharmas of the king?
Great King, you should know!
In brief, there are five kinds that can skillfully give rise to the lovable dharmas of the king. What are the five?
First, being kind and caring to the world; second, being heroic and courageous; third, having skillful means; fourth, properly enjoying sense objects; fifth, diligently cultivating wholesome dharmas.
What is meant by the king being kind and caring to the people?
It means that the king is by nature content, able to be prudent, and has accomplished the pure dharma of being free from greed;
He gives to the poor and helpless from his storehouses according to his ability. He is gentle and patient, and often uses soft words to admonish the country.
If there are ministers who have committed offenses that cannot be overlooked, he measures their crimes and shows mercy, punishing them in accordance with the truth and the time.
This is called the king's righteous governance and nurturing of the people, and thus he inspires the respect and love of the world.
What is meant by the king being endowed with heroism?
It means that the king's divine strategy does not fail, and his martial prowess is perfect. He subdues those who have not yet been subdued, and protects those who have been subdued.
This is called the king being endowed with heroism.
What is meant by the king being endowed with skillful means?
It means that the king clearly understands all good things and is able to skillfully harmonize and embrace the strong factions, thereby subduing all enemies.
What is meant by the king properly receiving the realm?

It means that a king is good at calculating the increase and decrease of the treasury, not extravagant, not stingy, and uses it equally. According to the season, he provides what is appropriate to his ministers, aides, relatives, kings, and musicians.
Moreover, when he is sick, he should eat what is suitable and avoid what is unsuitable. He observes the nature of food and then eats it.
If the food has not yet been digested, or if he has diarrhea after eating, he should not eat.
What should be eaten together should not be eaten alone. The essence of the food should be distributed to make them happy.
This is called the king's proper enjoyment of the realm, which can skillfully nourish his own body.
What is meant by the king diligently cultivating good dharmas?

It means that a king is endowed with pure faith, precepts, learning, generosity, and wisdom. In the matter of pure faith, he understands faith in the afterlife and faith in the good and bad karma, the rewards and retributions of humans and gods in the future. This is called being endowed with pure faith.

Upholding pure precepts, during the three long months and six monthly observances, refraining from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, and drinking alcohol, is called the king's fulfillment of pure precepts;

In the place of pure hearing, in the present life's karma and future fruits, cultivating virtue and progressing in work, delighting in listening to the wondrous Dharma gates of prajÃ±Ä, single-mindedly and diligently penetrating to the end, is called the king's fulfillment of pure hearing;
In the place of pure renunciation, far from stinginess and greed, opening the hand to give, always cultivating blessings, perfectly impartial, is called the king's fulfillment of pure renunciation.

It means in the place of fulfilling pure wisdom, truly knowing what is sinful and what is not, what is cultivated and what is not, the superior and inferior skillful means, befriending the Å›ramaá¹‡as who are well-versed in precepts, and avoiding those who follow evil and false teachings. One should well know the three kinds of:
Perfect fruition, perfect function, and perfect virtue.

Namely, the king's lineage continues the imperial legacy, and his born relatives are intelligent and wise. The treasury and wealth are used without shortage. This is called the perfection of karmic retribution.
If the kings are always accomplished in skillful means, courageous in advancing and retreating, and well-versed in arts and abilities, this is called the perfection of human effort.
If the kings uphold the true Dharma and together with the inner palace, princes, and ministers practice generosity and good deeds;
observe the precepts and cultivate the door of loving-kindness and the supreme pure conduct;
frequently perform homa rituals to pacify and increase benefits;
and establish maá¹‡á¸alas and fully receive abhiá¹£eka, this is the perfection of merit.
If one is able to practice in this way, it is called the perfection of pure wisdom.
Furthermore, great king, you should know!
I have briefly explained the faults of a king, the virtues of a king, the doors to a king's decline, the lovable qualities of a king, and the methods for generating a king's lovable qualities.

Therefore, if the great king reads or recites this secret royal teaching every morning and practices in accordance with it, he will be called a righteous king, a Dharma king. The buddhas, bodhisattvas, and the eight groups of spiritual beings will day and night empower him, always protect him, and enable him to experience timely winds and rains in the world, to have the weapons of war put to rest, to receive tribute from all countries, to have boundless blessings and virtues, to have peace and stability in the country, and to have a long life span. Therefore, he will attain all benefits and happiness in this life.
At that time, King Udayana, having heard the Buddha's teachings, rejoiced and respectfully accepted them.
The Sutra on Governance for Kings Spoken by the Buddha for King Udayana
